ratings.comment: Poor attitude and condescending when you ask him a question. Asked him for help with a problem and it gave flashbacks to when your parents were getting angry trying to help you understand addition in 1st grade as you cried. After we submitted the answer from his help, it was wrong. If you have to take his class, ask for help from the TA's.
avoid at all costs

Good professor, who explains well

Super understanding and accommodating, just a little strict sometimes

I'm commenting back after working 2 years in industry after deg in Computer Eng. Thinking back on my undergrad, his main concepts are pretty spot on. Back then I was still trying to reinvent the wheel, his lectures were already way ahead.

Yea its true that he talks with this weird condescending way of talking. There were times I was just confused on how to start, and there would be a weird/bad atmosphere. The TAs were very helpful 10/10. It ended up that I would scout the room to only raise my hand if a TA was near and he was looking/at somewhere else.

Definitely acts a little conceited, but he gets the job done. Only problem I had with him was that he was never at his assigned office hours, at least when I went. Besides that, I thought the class had a good layout and I learned a lot from the triweekly group exercises.

Professor Van der Weide is an incredibly boring lecturer and goes off on many topics that are tangential to what he is teaching. He speaks slowly so his lectures feel much longer than they should. When students ask questions he is usually condescending. I asked a question 2 weeks into the course and he responded with, "this is a day one question."

Had him for 340 and regretted it. Doesn't explain things very well and the course (online due to covid) wasn't organized well at all. Tests were extremely hard and aren't represented well in the HW or even in lectures. Also the textbook used is also poorly organized. Maybe the class is better in-person but it was pretty bad online.
This man is condescending to every comment or question you might have. Would recommend taking a semester off to avoid taking his class.
The actual organization of class content is horrendous leading to confusion all over the place

Avoid at all costs for 340. Good luck. He's condescending and is very unclear in lectures, the example problems often don't relate to actual test/hw problems. Makes the class incredibly hard and sometimes assigns work with less than a day to complete it. You'll be teaching this class by yourself and expect to spend lots of time in TA office hours.

Dan was a fine professor for this class, but had a few issues. He was very knowledgeable about the material, but could be condescending to students at times when asked questions that were more basic. He ran the class fine, but wasn't the most pleasant instructor I have ever had. ECE 230 is somewhat challenging, but definitely manageable with him.

I can't speak on 230 or 340, but in 447, the density of microwave engineering you pick up in just one semester is unbelievable. He's obviously passionate about the material, with lectures motivating and clarifying subjects you'll (have to) read in the textbook. Exams are 24hr take-home with fair difficulty. Best course I've taken in the department.

Not only is professor Van Der Weide condescending, but he's also a terrible teacher. If you take him for 340, you'll have to teach yourself, since all he does is assign readings and TopHat questions. What lectures he does give are unrelated to the in class (graded) exercises, so if you want to do well you must read entire book chapters before class

Absolutely terrible professor. The worst prof I've ever had in my 3 years so far. When ever you ask him a question he responds with condescending and snooty responses. He thinks you're stupid for asking simple questions. Mid terms are nothing like the practice exams. The TA doesn't know whats going on and gives wrong answers as solutions. Avoid him

AWFUL professor. Unclear syllabus. Rambles when giving lectures. Assigns homework due within the next 5 hours on tophat but barely knows how to use tophat. Haven't taken a midterm yet, not looking forward to it. I did very well in ECE 230 but I will be lucky to pass 340, even when putting in 100% effort.

Does not teach students in class, had to learn everything on our own. Going to his lecture is like we are not on the same level, both intellectually and personally. Mark Allie has to sit in our class because he's so bad. I did not heed people's warning on here, unless you are super smart (be humble), DO NOT TAKE, DO NOT TAKE, DO NOT TAKE

Incredibly smart man. If you want to learn, he is a jackpot of knowledge. Very nice when you get to know him. I have learned more by taking 447 than everything in my 4 previous years combined. Highly recommend!

He is not organized. Video before class is over 30 min long and he talks really slow. Material covered in class doesn't help you get ready for exams. Final exam counts toward 40% of the grade. DO NOT TAKE. DO NOT TAKE. DO NOT TAKE.

His class is poorly designed (watch lecture videos like other ECE courses except no in-class problems, more lecturing). He recorded the videos the night before and clearly did not create a lesson plan as he made fairly simple topics confusing. He moved the final exam date on us twice, after people had already made travel arragements. Do not take.

Easily the worst professor I've had at the school. Most of the class stopped showing up to lecture halfway through the semester. I'm certain they were better off than I was after attending lecture every day.
Absolutely horrible. Avoid like the plague. Makes this class so much worse then it needs to be.

He cannot communicate on the same level that students will understand. Don't expect questions to be answered at all. Quizzes are on material that hasn't been taught yet, just expected to understand from the book. All in depth learning and equations are from the book and he touches briefly on the most general examples. DO NOT TAKE

Uses terminology beyond what you know coming in so you never know what he is saying (including on tests, midterm had a couple terms that you had to guess what they meant). Focuses on small details. Doesn't do any examples ever. Pre-lecture quizzes cover content in that lecture so essentially your expected to completely teach yourself this class.

2 pre-class quizzes each week which contain a mix of bizarrely worded (sometimes incorrect) questions, as well as overly-easy questions and should've been asked weeks prior.  He talks about trivial points for most of class, then brushes over difficult points in the last 5 minutes.  I've learned hardly anything for the time I've spent on this class.

Online quizzes due twice a week before lectures on material covered after the quiz is due. Frequent errors and ambiguities on quizzes. Professor did a 2 minute "review" on Bode Plots despite them not being covered in previous courses. Half of Midterm 1 was about a concept briefly covered in 1 lecture. Teaching style is not engaging.

I do not know about how he performs in other courses but for ECE340 (Electronic Circuits), avoid him at all cost. For someone working in ECE, the teaching style is veeery outdated, he assumes students know way more than they actually do (applied to many many people I know when I took the course), gives out unreasonable quiz questions twice a week.

Too "busy" to meet outside of class, even if you set up a time in advance.  Will walk away from you when you are trying to ask a question.  Expects you to just read the book and know everything, lectures are slow, do not cover any material in-depth.  Trivial problems done during lecture which does not prepare students well for homework and quizzes.
